items.title: Millions brace for cyclonic winds and wild conditions across Victoria and SA
items.standfirst: Residents across south-east Victoria have been warned that se vere weather is forecast for most of today, including wild afternoon storms and cyclonic wind gusts reaching up over 100km/h.
items.content: I t is a tale of two very different cities today as millions brace for wild winds and a downpour in Melbourne, while Sydneysiders prepare to sizzle under a spring heatwave.Residents across south-east Victoria, including Melbourne, have been warned that se vere weather is forecast for most of today, including wild afternoon storms and cyclonic wind gusts reaching up over 100km/h.The Bureau of Meterology issued an early-morning severe weather warning at 4am for most of the state.READ MORE: 'Is he a nice guy?': Albanese reveals new details of Trump encounterREAD MORE: City braced for its hottest October day on recordA low pressure system which developed off the southern coast of SA is now moving east and will bring with it damaging wind gusts this afternoon and into tomorrow morning, the BoM said.Locations expected to be impacted include greater Melbourne, Horsham, Warrnambool, Bendigo, Shepparton, Seymour, Maryborough, Ballarat, Geelong, Wangaratta, Traralgon and Bairnsdale.Cape Otway on Victoria's southern coast is forecast to be battered by the most destructive winds reaching up to 130km/h winds.Gale-force winds reaching from 100 to 120 km/h are also expected to develop over the far south-west later tomorrow morning, moving towards Geelong and the Mornington Peninsula during the early afternoon, and into south Gippsland on the mid to late afternoon.The state's emergency service has told residents to avoid standing or parking under trees and to be aware of loose items which could turn into missiles during strong winds.WorkSafe Chief Health and Safety Officer Sam Jenkin also warned employers to keep staff safe during the wild conditions."When winds pick up, unsecured materials and unstable structures can collapse, crush or strike workers and members of the public," Jenkin said.LIVE UPDATES: Major weather events facing millions; Record breaking heat expected in NSW"Every site needs a clear strategy for managing severe weather so tools, materials and debris don't become flying hazards."Jenkin pointed out that cranes were particularly vulnerable to tip-overs or structural damage during severe weather events."Workers and members of the public were lucky to avoid injury when a tower crane collapsed in similar conditions on a Derrimut construction site in August, bringing down power lines and causing extensive damage," he added."This shows how quickly things can go wrong and the importance of following manufacturer instructions for stowage or configuration of cranes during high winds like we're expecting across the state today."Thunderstorms later today are also likely, however only light rain of up to 5mm in the Melbourne metro area is expected.The wild weather is set to ease tomorrow, with only moderate winds forecast for south-east Victoria.Destructive weather battering SASimilar conditions are also expected across South Australia today and tomorrow.The BoM has issued s evere weather warnings for damaging and locally destructive winds, marine wind warnings, and a sheep graziers warning across the state.The most destructive winds are expected in the Mount Lofty Ranges, Kangaroo Island, Upper South East, Lower South East and parts of the Mid North and Murraylands districts.There is also a risk of locally destructive gusts along the coast south-east of Robe.Adelaide is forecast to be drenched with around 30mm of rain today as storms develop into the afternoon.READ MORE: New accusations come to light as Virginia Giuffre's memoir is releasedhttps://x.com/BOM_SA/status/1980720552626020618Bushfire warning in NSW as millions face catastrophic heatMultiple fire bans are in place in NSW, including for Sydney, as the state braces for more soaring temperatures after its hottest October day on record.The Bureau of Meteorology has cancelled a heatwave warning for NSW but Sydney is still set to hit a top of 39 degrees today.And fire bans have been imposed on the greater metro region, as well as other areas including the Illawarra and Hunter. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Victoria’s top cop apologises after taking police helicopter across Bass Strait to Tasmania
items.standfirst: Mike Bush says commercial flight would have been more appropriate for travel to Hobart for meeting of commissionersFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe Victorian police commissioner who used one of the force’s helicopters to fly nearly 600km from Melbourne to Tasmania to attend a conference has apologised for his “mistake”.The chief commissioner, Mike Bush, used Victoria police’s “secondary” helicopter to cross the Bass Strait and attend a meeting with his counterparts in Hobart – where a mechanical issue caused it to be grounded on Monday night. Continue reading...

items.title: White House lauds Albanese-Trump meeting in social media video
items.standfirst: The White House has released a glowing video celebrating the rapport between Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump after the pair signed a $8.5 billion critical minerals deal.
items.content: The White House has released a glowing video celebrating the rapport between Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump after the pair signed a $8.5 billion critical minerals deal.A video montage of yesterday's landmark meeting, posted to the White House's official social media channels, featured clips of the leaders and uplifting music playing in the background. "A lot of friends over there and this is one of them right here," Trump said in the video as he gestured towards Albanese.READ MORE: PM's plane forced into unscheduled stop on way home from successful White House visit " We work together very much on rare earths, critical minerals and lots of other things."Albanese echoed Trump's sentiments, describing the pair as "great friends" and "great allies" ."Today's agreement on critical minerals and rare earths is just taking it to the next level," Albanese said.READ MORE: Awkward Trump and Rudd moment in historic meeting"I think that today will be seen as a really significant day in our relationship, so I thank you very much, Mr President."Albanese told Today this morning the pair had a "warm meeting" conducted across several hours, which ended in the critical minerals deal as well as Trump's vocal backing for the AUKUS agreement."He's a friend of Australia," Albanese said.READ MORE: 'Nice guy': PM reveals extra details about Trump-Rudd clash However, the meeting hit a sour note when Trump was asked about since-deleted comments Rudd made online prior to his ambassadorial appointment, in which the former PM said Trump was "destructive" and "a traitor to the West"."I don't like you, and I probably never will," Trump said to Rudd at yesterday's meeting, prompting laughter.Albanese confirmed reports Rudd had apologised to Trump for the comments once the cameras were off, with the US president declaring: "All is forgiven."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Morning Mail: US pushes for Aukus tweaks, environment reforms to target company profits, and how to keep pets cool
items.standfirst: Want to get this in your inbox every weekday? Sign up for the Morning Mail here, and finish your day with our Afternoon Update newsletterMorning everyone. After a very successful first day in Washington DC, Anthony Albanese has faced questions over so-called “ambiguity” in the Aukus deal which the US wants to change.At home, Murray Watt has given us an exclusive interview about his plans to reform the country’s environmental laws, we report on how some big companies pay more in bonuses than they do in tax, and how to keep your pets cool as the heatwave hits the east.Exclusive | The Albanese government wants the power to strip companies of any financial gains made from breaking environment laws as part of a package of reforms to be put before parliament in the next two weeks. Speaking to Guardian Australia, the environment minister, Murray Watt, said he also wants a definition of “unacceptable impact” to be enshrined in law.Aukus ‘updates’ | Anthony Albanese continued his visit to Washington today and indicated the United States could seek updates to the Aukus agreement. It comes after a day after Donald Trump’s navy secretary spoke of his hopes to “clarify some of the ambiguity” in the nuclear submarine deal. Although the rare earths deal that Albanese signed with Trump involves mines that are probably not commercially viable, the deal “couldn’t have gone any better” according to one leading expert.Business bonus | Some of the nation’s biggest companies – including CSL, Optus and Santos – regularly spend more on bonuses for their chief executives than they pay in company tax in Australia, new analysis shows.Cult question | Two Christian lobby groups have pushed back against any new laws to protect vulnerable people from cults with an inquiry in Victoria told of a “palpable fear” they could affect mainstream churches.Gold rush | The ABC Bullion Sydney store has seen huge queues as investors trade out of shares and currencies and into gold thanks to the huge increase in price. That being said, the precious metal saw its biggest one-day fall since 2020 overnight. Continue reading...

It comes after a day after Donald Trump’s navy secretary spoke of his hopes to “clarify some of the ambiguity” in the nuclear submarine deal. That being said, the precious metal saw its biggest one-day fall since 2020 overnight. Continue reading...

items.title: Albanese backs Rudd to keep role despite Trump criticism, saying ambassador ‘works his guts out’ in DC
items.standfirst: Donald Trump had told Kevin Rudd he ‘probably never will’ like him, prompting apology from ambassadorFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAnthony Albanese has strongly backed Kevin Rudd to remain as US ambassador, saying he “works his guts out”, and downplayed an awkward interaction with Donald Trump during their White House meeting.It came after a prominent Republican congressman addressed Rudd in a speech in Washington DC, jokingly telling him: “I’m glad you’re still gainfully employed.” Continue reading...

items.title: Albanese hints US could still seek changes to Aukus agreement amid review
items.standfirst: Speaking in Washington, the prime minister downplayed US comments about ‘ambiguity’ but conceded he knows that the Pentagon want some updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAnthony Albanese has indicated the United States could seek updates to the Aukus agreement a day after Donald Trump’s navy secretary spoke of his hopes to “clarify some of the ambiguity” in the nuclear submarine deal, amid an ongoing Pentagon review.The prime minister downplayed the comments from naval secretary John Phelan, telling media “don’t look for something that’s not there” and noting Trump’s strong support for the plan to even be accelerated. Following successful meetings with President Trump and senior US politicians in Washington DC, Albanese boasted of the substantial support for the agreement on Capitol Hill, and revealed he even presented Trump with a gift of a model submarine. Continue reading...

Following successful meetings with President Trump and senior US politicians in Washington DC, Albanese boasted of the substantial support for the agreement on Capitol Hill, and revealed he even presented Trump with a gift of a model submarine. items.title: Pat Conroy says China’s claims RAAF aircraft illegally entered its airspace ‘factually incorrect’ – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closedTurnbull hails Albanese’s handling of Trump meeting but warns ‘warm words don’t build submarines’Australia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal to take on China’s monopoly. Here’s what you need to knowGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe foreign affairs minister was asked about Donald Trump’s remark that he didn’t like the Australian ambassador, Kevin Rudd, and “probably never will” during the White House meeting early this morning.Trump made the testy remark, telling Rudd “I don’t like you either”, at the White House cabinet room table, prompting uncomfortable laughter. Penny Wong told RN the ambassador had done an “extremely good job” getting the meeting between the US president and Albanese:Look, I think those comments were clearly tongue-in-cheek. I’m very pleased that the meeting has been such a success. That is a good thing for our country. It’s extremely good to have this critical minerals deal backed in, and it’s extremely positive for the country to have the president so supportive of Aukus and the delivery of the submarines, which is an important capability for us.Kevin did an extremely good job not only in getting the meeting but doing the work on the critical minerals deal. And the meeting reflects the success of that work. Continue reading...
items.content: This blog is now closedTurnbull hails Albanese’s handling of Trump meeting but warns ‘warm words don’t build submarines’Australia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal to take on China’s monopoly. Here’s what you need to knowGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe foreign affairs minister was asked about Donald Trump’s remark that he didn’t like the Australian ambassador, Kevin Rudd, and “probably never will” during the White House meeting early this morning.Trump made the testy remark, telling Rudd “I don’t like you either”, at the White House cabinet room table, prompting uncomfortable laughter. Penny Wong told RN the ambassador had done an “extremely good job” getting the meeting between the US president and Albanese:Look, I think those comments were clearly tongue-in-cheek. I’m very pleased that the meeting has been such a success. That is a good thing for our country. It’s extremely good to have this critical minerals deal backed in, and it’s extremely positive for the country to have the president so supportive of Aukus and the delivery of the submarines, which is an important capability for us.Kevin did an extremely good job not only in getting the meeting but doing the work on the critical minerals deal. And the meeting reflects the success of that work. Continue reading...

items.title: Key moments from Albanese and Trump's White House meeting – video
items.standfirst: The Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, has met with the US president, Donald Trump, officially for the first time in person. At a meeting in the White House, Trump heaped praise on Albanese's leadership as the pair signed a US$8.5bn rare earths deal and Trump assured Australia of the US's commitment to the Aukus submarine deal. It wasn't all rosy – Trump told former Australian PM Kevin Rudd, who is now the ambassador to the US, 'I don't like you and I probably never will'. Trump was asked about Rudd's former negative comments about the president. Trump also chided three Australian reporters, but praised one for his haircut.► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeAlbanese at the White House: Trump endorses Aukus, signs $8.5bn rare earths deal and calls PM ‘great leader’‘I don’t like you either’: diplomats hold their breath as Trump chides Rudd over previous comments Continue reading...
items.content: The Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, has met with the US president, Donald Trump, officially for the first time in person. At a meeting in the White House, Trump heaped praise on Albanese's leadership as the pair signed a US$8.5bn rare earths deal and Trump assured Australia of the US's commitment to the Aukus submarine deal. It wasn't all rosy – Trump told former Australian PM Kevin Rudd, who is now the ambassador to the US, 'I don't like you and I probably never will'. Trump was asked about Rudd's former negative comments about the president. Trump also chided three Australian reporters, but praised one for his haircut.► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeAlbanese at the White House: Trump endorses Aukus, signs $8.5bn rare earths deal and calls PM ‘great leader’‘I don’t like you either’: diplomats hold their breath as Trump chides Rudd over previous comments Continue reading...

items.title: Why the Australia-US rare earths deal matters so much for Trump
items.standfirst: P rime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump are crowing about the agreement, but will it make Australia a big player in critical minerals?
items.content: P rime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump have signed an $US8.5 billion ($13 billion) critical minerals and rare earths agreement in a move to break China's stranglehold on the market.The US–Australia Critical Minerals Framework puts rare earths squarely at the forefront of the Australian-US relationship, with Albanese saying there is a "pipeline that we have ready to go".The deal will kick off with both countries paying $US1 billion over the next six months for new projects.READ MORE: 'I don't like you': Trump blasts Rudd during Albo meetingTrump was delighted in securing the agreement with Australia. China earlier this month ramped up restrictions on its rare earth exports. That didn't sit well with the US president, who threatened to call off an upcoming meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping."We work together very much on rare earths, critical minerals and lots of other things, and we've had a very good relationship," Trump said as he sat beside Albanese at the White House."We've been working on that for quite a while."In about a year from now, we'll have so much critical mineral and rare earths, and you won't know what to do with them."READ MORE: World's biggest apps and websites hit by global outageWhat are rare earths?Rare earths include 17 metallic elements in the periodic table made up of scandium, yttrium and the lanthanides.The name "rare earths" is a bit of a misnomer, because the materials are found throughout the Earth's crust.They are more abundant than gold, but they are difficult and costly to extract and process and are also environmentally damaging.The minerals are used to make everyday technologies, from smartphones to wind turbines to LED lights and flat-screen TVs.They're crucial for batteries in electric vehicles, as well as MRI scanners and cancer treatments.Rare earths are also essential for the arms industry and the US armed forces, the world's biggest.They're used in F-35 fighter jets, submarines, lasers, satellites, Tomahawk missiles and more, according to the Centre for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a US think tank.READ MORE: Chilling warning over 3D-printed guns flooding Australia amid crackdownWhy is Australia so crucial?The US sees Australia, a long-standing ally, as an alternative source for rare earths as the critical minerals shape up to become a major hurdle in Washington-Beijing relations.China is the world's largest producer of rare earth elements, with 61 per cent of mined rare earth production, according to the International Energy Agency, and 92 per cent of the global output in the processing stag e. Trump hopes the Australia deal will help break that monopoly.Australia offers three major attractions: it has some of the world's biggest geological reserves : a share market with a record of successfully investing in mining; and a skilled labour force.Are there any hurdles ahead? Economic geographer Lian Sinclair, of the University of Sydney, says vast sums of money are pouring into the Australian rare earths industry: $3.2 billion by Australian government agencies; $2.9 billion from foreign allied governments, including the US, Japan, South Korea and Canada."This is a large amount for an industry with a total global trade of less than US$4 billion ($6 billion) every year," he said. It means without investment in refineries and magnet production in allied countries, Australian miners will continue to either sell into or be outcompeted by Chinese domestic industry.Sinclair says apart from Australian rare-earths mining company Lynas, which sells into the Japanese market, miners are struggling to find potential international buyers.To wean themselves off Chinese rare earths for wind turbines and electric vehicles, the US, Europe and South Korea need to heavily invest in magnet and advanced metal processing industries.Sinclair also points to the environmental cost of Australia becoming a big player in rare earths, with more work needed to be done in planning for managing radioactive waste and building partnerships with First Nations people. - With CNN DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Diplomatic triumph or ‘capitulation’? Albanese found Donald Trump in a heavenly mood but the devil may be in the detail
items.standfirst: Fresh from a tropical holiday, the Australian prime minister caught the US president at his effusive best‘I don’t like you either’: diplomats hold their breath as Trump chides Rudd over previous commentsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAnthony Albanese was so pleased about his first meeting with Donald Trump, so chuffed with the overwhelming – and somewhat unexpected – praise from the president, the prime minister joked that he’d use the endorsements in his campaign ads at the next election.That’s obviously unlikely to happen – consider the effective campaign Albanese ran against Peter Dutton by comparing him to Trump, and the Labor left flank already ropable over what they view as a fawning and “shameful capitulation” over Aukus and critical minerals. Continue reading...

items.title: Southern states warned to brace for storms, 'rare' destructive winds
items.standfirst: Damaging winds are expected to cut power and bring down trees across parts of South Australia, Victoria and NSW tomorrow.
items.content: Multiple Aussie states are set to be hammered by fierce winds, rain and thunderstorms as a low pressure system batters the country's south-east.Damaging winds are expected to cut power and bring down trees across parts of South Australia, Victoria and NSW today.Coupled with a cold front, the weather system has already lashed SA with strong winds yesterday as it tracks south-easterly towards western Victoria.READ MORE: Millions set to swelter as spring scorcher looms"Tomorrow is going to be amongst the windiest days, if not the windiest day of the springtime ," meteorologist Angus Hines said.Strong winds were expected to intensify overnight and move into eastern parts of Victoria and NSW today.Severe weather warnings were in place across SA, Victoria and NSW, with wind gusts reaching 90km/h to 110km/h expected in some areas overnight.Residents in the south-east of South Australia, most of Victoria and parts of south-east and eastern NSW, including the Blue Mountains and the Illawarra, are warned to brace for the brunt of the fierce conditions.READ MORE: Which apps and websites were affected by the Amazon Web Services outage?"It will be Wednesday morning where the winds are strongest in south-west Victoria," Hines said yesterday."That is where we will see the potential for those gusts over 120km/h, which is rare to see winds of that speed."Coastal areas between Cape Otway in Victoria and Robe in South Australia are expected to receive destructive wind gusts up to 120km/h to 130km/h this morning.Emergency services are warning residents to brace for damage to property, cars and power lines as destructive winds threaten to topple trees and branches.Severe storms and heavy rain are also forecast for northern parts of Tasmania with rainfall totals up to 50 millimetres in parts of the state.Conditions across the south-east part of the country are expected to stabilise this evening as the system moves offshore.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: 'A great friend': Young Australians on their relationships with AI chatbots
items.standfirst: Some Australians would rather stay home and talk to an AI bot than go out with friends, according to a YouGov survey.
items.content: Some Australians would rather stay home and talk to an AI bot than go out with friends, according to a YouGov survey.

ai_summary: Some young Australians are forming relationships with AI chatbots.
A YouGov survey indicates this trend among the younger population.
Some prefer interacting with AI bots over social outings with friends.
The survey explores the evolving social dynamics of young people.
The findings highlight the growing influence of AI in social interactions.

clusters.title: Road accident compensation not culturally safe, study says
clusters.neutral_headline: Road Accident Compensation Not Culturally Safe, Study Finds

items.title: Road accident compensation not culturally safe, study says
items.standfirst: A first-of-its-kind South Australian study finds access to compensation after a road accident is not good enough for First Nations people.
items.content: A first-of-its-kind South Australian study finds access to compensation after a road accident is not good enough for First Nations people.

ai_summary: A South Australian study reveals issues with road accident compensation.
The study focuses on the experiences of First Nations people.
Access to compensation is not considered adequate for this group.
The study is the first of its kind in South Australia.
The findings highlight the need for improvements in the system.

clusters.title: Critical minerals deal tipped to unlock Australia's 'next chapter of prosperity'
clusters.neutral_headline: Critical Minerals Deal Could Boost Australian Prosperity

items.title: Critical minerals deal tipped to unlock Australia's 'next chapter of prosperity'
items.standfirst: Australian critical minerals companies could expect more international and domestic investment in producing and processing following the deal, experts say, however, more investment is needed in refineries and magnet production.
items.content: Australian critical minerals companies could expect more international and domestic investment in producing and processing following the deal, experts say, however, more investment is needed in refineries and magnet production.

ai_summary: A critical minerals deal is expected to boost Australian investment.
International and domestic investment is expected to increase.
Investment is needed in refineries and magnet production.
Experts believe the deal will unlock the next chapter of prosperity.
The deal focuses on the production and processing of critical minerals.
